Award.AwardTitle: US Ignite Next Generation Applications Hub Design Workshop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
US Ignite was launched in 2012 to foster the development of next-generation apps for public benefit. In the next 5 years, US Ignite efforts are targeting the development of 60 next-generation applications, 200 community testbeds, and a forum for collaboration between industry, academia, and gigabit communities. Because US Ignite services a broad range of stakeholders in next-generation app development, the activities of the partnership are not always clearly visible. US Ignite, and the overall goals of the partnership, are better served by transparent, shared communications infrastructure.

This project addresses part of this need by convening a platform design workshop to solicit feedback, ideas, and expertise from key stakeholders and drive the development of a new web-based platform for the development of next generation applications. The platform will serve as a hub for research and best practices in software-defined networking, symmetric gigabit networks, local cloud computing and other advanced networking applications. It will include an index of a variety of advanced networking application projects and demonstrate how these networks can be used. Additionally, by providing opportunities for engagement and collaboration across diverse groups that do not naturally interact, the platform provides possibilities for the discovery of new ideas and potentially transformative applications. During this workshop the participants will: identify and define key priorities of leadership and stakeholders; agree on core user demographics and needs; define the site design (look and feel) and requirements (functionality); identify existing content that can be leveraged to bootstrap the site; and agree to development roadmap and schedule. The goal of the workshop is to prepare fully the development team to operationalize this platform and build a sustainable next-generation apps development community.

The workshop will result in a roadmap and core group to produce a platform that will increase participation in the next-generation apps community. It will provide a consolidated gateway to people, software, and documentation. It will enable the small team at US Ignite to scale up this ecosystem and reach a broader audience. It will also decrease the development time from idea to usable application and propel applications out of the lab and into [the] community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
US Ignite is working to create an ecosystem of applications for gigabit “smart” networks. Mozilla is a global non-profit dedicated to shaping the future of Internet as a public resource.

Mozilla and US Ignite worked together to create a platform that will serve gigabit app developers, communities, and technology providers. This portal consolidates us- ignite.org and mozillaignite.org, creating an index of next-generation applications, and providing a single gateway for participation in the US Ignite initiative. It links tangible resources contributed by corporate partners (advanced broadband equipment, engineering time, and access to high-capacity networks) with intellectual capital contributed by the over 100 US Ignite corporate, developer, and community partners.

There are a variety of use cases for us-ignite.org. Say a university researcher seeks a design partner to work on an experimental consumer application for gigabit networks. She can post an application on us-ignite.org, and perhaps university student, who has been recruited by US Ignite, will become interested in collaborating and contact her. Or perhaps the developers of a telerobotics application are looking for GENI-connected universities who want to pilot their software. They can list their application at US Ignite and search for institutional partners in GENI-connected cities.


In 2014, Mozilla and US Ignite (http://us-ignite.org) convened a platform design workshop to solicit feedback, ideas, and expertise from key stakeholders in order to develop an online platform. The goal of the project was to: 1) convene a platform design workshop; 2) prepare a development team to operationalize this platform and 3) build a sustainable next-generation apps development community.

During this workshop the participants identified and defined key priorities of leadership and stakeholders; agreed on core user demographics and needs; defined the site design (look and feel) and requirements (functionality); identified existing content that can be leveraged to bootstrap the site; and agree to development roadmap and schedule.

Through the workshop and follow-up activities, Mozilla has successfully completed the collaboration with US Ignite, and this platform is now operational at http://us-ignite.org.  The source code is available at https://github.com/us-ignite/us_ignite.
